pages.text: The $(l)Named Binary Tag (NBT)$() is a tree data structure used by Minecraft in many save files to store arbitrary data. $(br2)$(l)Stringified Named Binary Tag (SNBT)$(), also known as data tag, is often used in $(l:commands)$(thing)Commands$(). $(br2)A data tag consists of zero or more attribute-value pairs delimited by commas and enclosed in curly braces.

Each attribute-value pair consists of a tag name and the tag's value, separated by a colon. $(br2)Some values, however, may be a compound tag and themselves contain attribute-value pairs, allowing a data tag to describe a hierarchical data structure. $(br2)$(n)Example:$() $(br2)$(o){CustomName:'"Bob"', Invisible:true}$()

$(n)$(l)References:$()$(br) $(li)$(l:https://minecraft.fandom.com/wiki/NBT_format)Basic Knowledge$()  $(li)$(l:https://minecraft.fandom.com/wiki/Tutorials/Command_NBT_tags)Commands with NBT tutorial$()$(li)$(l:https://minecraft.fandom.com/wiki/Chunk_format#Block_entity_format)NBT for Block Entities$()  $(li)$(l:https://minecraft.fandom.com/wiki/Player.dat_format#Item_structure)NBT for Items$()  $(li)$(l:https://minecraft.fandom.com/wiki/Entity_format#Items_and_XPOrbs)NBT for Item Entities$()  $(li)$(l:https://minecraft.fandom.com/wiki/Entity_format#Mobs)NBT for Mobs$()  $(li)$(l:https://minecraft.fandom.com/wiki/Entity_format#Projectiles)NBT for Projectiles$()   $(li)$(l:https://minecraft.fandom.com/wiki/Entity_format#Vehicles)NBT for Vehicles$()  $(li)$(l:https://minecraft.fandom.com/wiki/Entity_format#Dynamic_Tiles)NBT for dynamic Tiles$()   $(li)$(l:https://minecraft.fandom.com/wiki/Entity_format#Other)NBT for other Entities$()
